name: Spam Analysis New - TheHive
description:
Phishing Story Checklist

Here's some things to double check are set up to ensure this story works smoothly!

*** Credentials ***

- URLScan.io API Key named 'urlscan_io'

- VirusTotal API Key named 'virustotal'

- HybridAnalysis API Key named 'HybridAnalysisAPI'

- emailrep.io API Key named 'emailrep'

- IPQualityScore API Key named 'ipqualityscore'

- Maxmind Licence Key named 'maxmind'

- The Hive API Key named 'the_hive_api_key'

- OAuth, JWT, or Text credential used to access the specified mailbox.


*** Resources ***

- Array Resource named 'known_good_domains' used to store domains that should not be scanned

- Array Resource named 'known_good_email_domains' used to store email domains that should not be scanned

- Text Resource named 'servicenowdomain' containing the domain of your ServiceNow instances (e.g. tines.service-now.com) 

- Text Resource named 'maxmind_account_id' containing the Maxmind Account ID

payload.sender_email:
{% assign sender_results = .implode_analysis | where: "build_results.type", 'sender' | map: 'build_results'%}

#### *Sender Analysis Results*

|*Email Address*|*Malicious*|*CEO Fraud*|*Blacklisted*|*Suspicious*|*Disposable Email*|*Domain Age*|
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
|{{.sender_results.first.raw.email_address}} |{% if .sender_results.first.raw.malicious == true %}❌ Malicious{% else %}✅ Not Malicious{% endif %} |{{.sender_results.first.raw.ceo_fraud}} |{{.sender_results.first.raw.email_blacklisted}} |{{.sender_results.first.raw.suspicious_email}} |{{.sender_results.first.raw.disposable_email}} |{{.sender_results.first.raw.email_domain_age}} |
payload.headers:
{% if analyze_headers %}#### *Header Analysis Results*

|*DMARC*|*SPF*|*DKIM*|*IP*|*ASN*|*IP Location*|*Recent Spam*|*IP Reputation*|
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
 |{{.analyze_headers.dmarc}}|{{.analyze_headers.spf}}|{{.analyze_headers.dkim}}|{{.analyze_headers.initial_ip}}|{{.analyze_headers.organization}}|{{.analyze_headers.city}},{{.analyze_headers.country}}|{{.analyze_headers.recent_spam_activity}}|{{.analyze_headers.ip_sender_reputation}}|{% endif %}

payload.message: Found in email with subject "{{.read_mail.subject }}" submitted by {{.add_reporter.reporter | default: .read_mail.from }}.

diagram_notes.content:
Tying Everything Together

This Implode Action will wait for all previous analysis to complete, and bring everything together in one event so we can prepare the results.

Imploding and Building Results

The Implode Action will wait until all attachments have been analyzed and results returned. It will then merge these results into one event which will be available later.

Build Results will summarise the results of attachment analysis and indicate whether any of the URLs were malicious, and how many attachments were analyzed in total.

IMAP Action

The IMAP action will connect to a mailbox where the mailserver is configured to have IMAP enabled.

Enter the mailserver, the username and the password to connect any begin reading mails.

The first time this Action is run, the mailbox state will be recorded and any future mails will be read into Tines on subsequent Action queries.

Analyzing URLs

Any URLs found in the body of the email are identified and extracted.

We're then exploding the array of extracted URLs so that we can look at these URLs individually.

Each URL will be analyzed by URLScan and VirusTotal. 
If a URL is identified as malicious, it will be added to TheHive case as an observable.

EML Handling

Some users or report phish buttons will forward the suspicious email as a .eml attachment.

In these cases, we want to identify these attachments and analyze this eml file including email headers.

Presenting the Results

In the Build The Hive Content Action we are going to build The Hive formatted content that the analyst will actually review.
The 'assign' block in this action is looking in the event output from Implode Analysis for the relevant analysis 'type'; URL, Attachment, Email, or Sender.
Any additions, or updates needed in The Hive Incident can be modified in the Build The Hive Content Action.

Analyzing Emails

In cases where the internal users reports the email by forwarding it inline, rather than as an attachment, we will want to check the body for any email addresses found, and check the reputation of these individually.

Imploding and Building Results

The Implode Action will wait until all email addresses have been analyzed and results returned. It will then merge these results into one event which will be available later.

Build Results will summarise the results of email address analysis and indicate whether any of the URLs were malicious, and how many email addresses were analyzed in total.

Imploding and Building Results

The Implode Action will wait until all URLs have been analyzed and results returned. It will then merge these results into one event which will be available later.

Build Results will summarise the results of URL analysis and indicate whether any of the URLs were malicious, and how many URLs were analyzed in total.

Creating Incident Ticket

Before any email content is analyzed we can create an issue in the security case management system.
This will contain basic mail info such as subject, body, and headers.

Analyzing Sender

To check the reputation of the sender of the suspicious email it is submitted to a Tines Sub-Story which will analyze the email address and return the results to this story.

Analyzing Attachments

Any attachments found in the reported email will be analyzed in this flow.

Each attachment will be analyzed individually in VirusTotal and HybridAnalysis. When set to 'true', the 'submit_if_not_found' field will upload the file to the scan engine if it has not been seen before. If set to 'false' or removed completely, it will not be submitted and the story will only pull back existing results.

Updating The Hive

First we're getting The Hive ticket content. We don't want to overwrite any information added to the case by an analyst while this Story was running, so we are updating The Hive case to include:

- An overall verdict on the mail
- The initial case description including mail body and headers
- Attachment, URL, Sender and Email analysis

Parsing the Mail

The mails come through as an Array, and using the Explode Action allows us to look at these individually

Next, we're marking the mail as read so we only process it once.
'Get Individual Email' is using the Email ID from previous events to retrieve the Raw email which will include extra information like the mail headers.
Lastly, this raw email content is being parse into a regular email structure.

Submitting by Form

This story is also able to receive eml files through the Tines Form. 
Any submitted EMLs will be received by this Webhook Action and will be processed as normal.

Handling Prompts

We are adding a couple of Trigger Actions here to handle Prompt Responses. If there is a Prompt included in The Hive incident - for example to Contain the Device in Crowdstrike - then these Actions will route the response to the right place.

Reading Mails with o365

The first Action here will connect to the Microsoft Graph API and retrieve a list of all unread mails.

We're including a pagination loop here will repeat the 'Get Mail' query if there are more available.

Reading Mails with GSuite

The first Action here will connect to the GMail API and retrieve a list of all mails received in the past 8 minutes or so. This Action should be scheduled to run every 5 minutes or so. The overlap between the schedule time, and the lookback time will ensure a mail does not get missed.

This Action uses an OAuth Token belonging to the Mailbox we're reading. This can also be a Service Account JWT Token, if necessary.

Parsing the Mail

The array of email IDs is being exploded into individual events so we can handle each mail by itself.

The Dedup Action will ensure that each mail is only examined once.

Next, using the original mail ID we can get the raw Base64Encoded Email Body, which we will then parse into the regular email format.

payload.verdicts: {% capture results%}[{% for scan in .search_hash_in_virustotal.body.data.attributes.last_analysis_results %}{% if scan[1].category == 'malicious' or scan[1].category == 'suspicious'%} {"Engine": "{{scan[0]}}", "Verdict": "{{scan[1].result}}"},{% endif %}{% endfor %}]{% endcapture %}{{ results | replace: ',]',' ]'  | json_parse | as_object }}

agents.name: File Not Found and No Submit

payload.malicious: Unknown - File not found in VirusTotal

payload.verdicts: {% capture results%}[{% for scan in .search_hash_in_virustotal.body.data.attributes.last_analysis_results %}{% if scan[1].category == 'malicious' or scan[1].category == 'suspicious'%} {"Engine": "{{scan[0]}}", "Verdict": "{{scan[1].result}}"},{% endif %}{% endfor %}]{% endcapture %}{{ results | replace: ',]', ' ]'  | json_parse | as_object }}

diagram_notes.content:
Checking the Hash

First we can search for the hash in VirusTotal and see if it is has been scanned before.

File Found!

If the file is found, we can go straight to the Build Results Action to extract relevant information and return it to the parent Story.

File Not Found

If the file has not been previously seen in VirusTotal then we can submit it, wait for the scan to complete, and then Build Results and return the analysis to the parent Story.

If this scan results in an error, then some information reflecting this will be returned.

This will only occur if the field 'submit_if_not_found' is explicitly set to 'true' in the parent Send to Story Action.

File Not Found

If the user has indicated that they do not want the file submitted to VirusTotal either by explicitly setting 'submit_if_not_found' to 'false, or by leaving out that field entirely, then we will bypass any further analysis.

The Build Analysis Results Action will contain some information indicating that the file hash was not found, and the file was not submitted.

agents.name: Check if Domain is Known Good

payload.malicious: {% if .retrieve_urlscan_result.body.verdicts.overall.malicious == false %}false{% else %}{{.retrieve_urlscan_result.body.verdicts.overall.malicious | default: 'error submitting' }}{% endif %}

diagram_notes.content:
Known Good Domains

There are some domains that that will not need to be submitted. These will be the company domain, such as 'tines.io', or other known good domains that frequently seen.

These domains can be stored in a Resource called 'known_good_email_domains'. This story will extract the domain from an email address, check if it is found in that Resource. If it is found, no check will be performed on that domain.

Domain is Known Good

If the domain is known good, then all analysis will be bypassed.
Results indicating this will be returned.

Submitting the URL Privately

By default, the URL will be submitted privately to URLScan. This means it will not show up in public searches - it will only be shown in your account.

Private submissions are limited on the free URLScan plan. This can be disabled setting 'public' to be on.
Alternatively additional URLScan plans are available to increase the amount of private submissions.

If URLScan returns a HTTP 429 (Too Many Requests) code, Tines will enter a retry sequence and will attempt the submission several more times.

Error Submitting

URLScan will respond with an error if the domain cannot be resolved, or if the domain owner has requested that their domain not be scanned (Like Facebook, or Linkedin).

Results indicating this will be returned.

Getting the Results

After submitting the URL, URLScan will provide a unique ID. We can use this to check on the status of the scan, and retrieve the results.

These results may include screenshots of the scanned URL. These will also be downloaded and made available to the parent story with the results of the scan.

agents.name: Search for Hash in Hybrid Analysis
File Not Found and No Submit

payload.malicious: Unknown - File not found, and not submitted

diagram_notes.content:
Checking the Hash

First we can search for the hash in HybridAnalysis and see if it is has been scanned before.

File Not Found

If the file has not been previously seen in HybridAnalysis then we can submit it, wait for the scan to complete, and then Build Analysis Results and return the analysis to the parent Story.

If this scan results in an error (or does not return in 20 mins), then some information reflecting this will be returned.

This will only occur if the field 'submit_if_not_found' is explicitly set to 'true' in the parent Send to Story Action.

File Found!

If the file is found, we can go straight to the Build Analysis Results Action to extract relevant information and return it to the parent Story.

File Not Found

If the user has indicated that they do not want the file submitted to HybridAnalysis either by explicitly setting 'submit_if_not_found' to 'false, or by leaving out that field entirely, then we will bypass any further analysis.

The Build Analysis Results Action will contain some information indicating that the file hash was not found, and the file was not submitted.

payload.malicious: Unknown - URL not found in VT, and not submitted

diagram_notes.content:
Domain is Known Good

If the domain is known good, then all analysis will be bypassed.
Results indicating this will be returned.

Known Good Domains

There are some domains that that will not need to be submitted. These will be the company domain, such as 'tines.io', or other known good domains that frequently seen.

These domains can be stored in a Resource called 'known_good_email_domains'. This story will extract the domain from an email address, check if it is found in that Resource. If it is found, no check will be performed on that domain.

URL Not Found

If the user has indicated that they do not want the url to be submitted to VirusTotal either by explicitly setting 'submit_if_not_found' to 'false, or by leaving out that field entirely, then we will bypass any further analysis.

The Build Analysis Results Action will contain some information indicating that the url was not found, and it was not submitted.

URL Not Found

If the url has not been previously seen in VirusTotal then we can submit it, wait for the scan to complete, and then Build Results and return the analysis to the parent Story.

If this scan results in an error, then some information reflecting this will be returned.

This will only occur if the field 'submit_if_not_found' is explicitly set to 'true' in the parent Send to Story Action.

agents.name: Search IP Rep in IP Quality Score

payload.recent_spam_activity: {% if .search_ip_rep_in_ip_quality_score.body.fraud_score >= 85 %}Identified spam in the past 24-48 hours{% elsif .search_ip_rep_in_ip_quality_score.body.fraud_score >= 75 %}Identified spam in the past month{% else %}Not associated with recent spam activity{% endif %}
payload.ip_sender_reputation: {% assign score = .search_ip_rep_in_ip_quality_score.body.fraud_score %}{% if score >=85 %}Bad{% elsif score >= 75 %}Poor{% elsif score >= 50 %}Suspicious{% elsif score >=11 %}OK{% elsif score <=10%}Good{% else %}unknown{% endif %}

payload.spf: {% if receive_headers.body.headers.Authentication-Results contains 'spf=pass' %}pass{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.Authenticaion-Results contains 'spf=fail' receive_headers.body.headers.Authenticaion-Results contains 'spf=softfail' %}fail{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.Authenticaion-Results contains 'spf=neutral' %}neutral{% else %}unknown{% endif %}
payload.dkim: {% if receive_headers.body.headers.Authentication-Results contains 'dkim=pass' %}pass{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.Authenticaion-Results contains 'dkim=fail' %}fail{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.Authenticaion-Results contains 'dkim=temperror' %}error{% else %}unknown{% endif %}
payload.dmarc: {% if receive_headers.body.headers.Authentication-Results contains 'dmarc=pass' %}pass{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.Authenticaion-Results contains 'dmarc=fail' %}fail{% else %}unknown{% endif %}

payload.spf: {% if receive_headers.body.headers.received-spf contains 'Fail' or receive_headers.body.headers.received-spf contains 'fail' %}fail{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.received-spf contains 'pass' %}pass{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.received-spf %}found{% else %}not_found{% endif %}
payload.dmarc: {% if receive_headers.body.headers.dmarc contains 'pass' or receive_headers.body.headers.dmarc contains 'Pass' %}pass{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.dmarc contains 'fail' or receive_headers.body.headers.dmarc contains 'Fail' %}fail{% elsif receive_headers.body.headers.dmarc %}found{% else %}not_found{% endif %}

diagram_notes.content:
Identify Originating IP

Checking to see if there are any IPs found in the mail headers.

If there are, the earliest identified IP will be extracted and analysed for reputation and location.

If no IPs are found, these checks will be skipped.

Identifying Spoofing

If an 'Authentication-Results' fields is identified, some regexes and checks will be run on this field to attempt to identify DMARC, SPF, and DKIM results.

If no 'Authentication-Results' is found, some attempts are made to look for these fields in the mail headers, and give some insight into whether the mail is failing any of these checks.

This is a best effort check as mail header format is not fully consistent or standard across providers.

Summarising Results

The Build Results Action will summarise and construct the results of this story and format them.

These fields will be returned to the parent Story.

payload.malicious: {% if .regex_for_ceo_fraud.rule_matched == true or .get_email_reputation.body.suspicious == true or .get_email_reputation.body.details.blacklisted == true%}true{% else %}false{% endif %}

diagram_notes.content:
Known Good Domains

There are some domains that that will not need to be submitted. These will be the company domain, such as 'tines.io', or other known good domains that frequently seen.

These domains can be stored in a Resource called 'known_good_email_domains'. This story will extract the domain from an email address, check if it is found in that Resource. If it is found, no check will be performed on that domain.

Analysing the Address

A regex pattern can be applied against the email address to identify if a scammer is attempting to impersonate the CEO or other executive. Multiple patterns can be separated by | characters to chain together regexes representing executive names.

After that, the email domain will be submitted to a service like emailrep.io. This will provide information such as domain age, if it is found on any blacklists, and if it should be considered suspicious.

Summarising Results

After analysis is complete, the results can be prepared and returned to the parent Story.

If the domain is not known good, the results from the CEO Fraud check, and the domain reputation check are summarisied.

If the domain is known to be good, then results will be returned reflecting that.
